3FF0CAB5ED4941EBBCF02CE75DC3C19F.description: explain Avogadro’s hypothesis and how his contribution to the gas laws has increased our understanding of the chemical reactions of gases

45D7976204344DFF8E03500C70EE531E.description: explain Dalton’s law of partial pressures, Boyle’s law, Charles’s law, Gay-Lussac’s law, the combined gas law, and the ideal gas law

341B7A5019184852861556C5F2885495.description: describe, for an ideal gas, the quantitative relationships that exist between the variables of pressure, volume, temperature, and amount of substance

28DBA5110346450AAE29605EAAE55222.description: use the kinetic molecular theory to explain the properties and behaviour of gases in terms of types and degrees of molecular motion

3DA46F8DD4064C4B9E044A5FE9FF9774.description: describe the different states of matter, and explain their differences in terms of the forces between atoms, molecules, and ions

4D8766FFC19841C08AADFF4A66C9586A.description: identify the major and minor chemical components of Earth's atmosphere

7616FB901E824B1E97D6A32505A73FC3.description: Understanding Basic Concepts: demonstrate an understanding of the laws that explain the behaviour of gases

5D94E204DDF94FF29B79D46E40284373.description: determine, through inquiry, the molar volume or molar mass of a gas produced by a chemical reaction (e.g., the molar volume of hydrogen gas from the reaction of magnesium with hydrochloric acid)

42A2AC2708EF4710BD487EA853F0C403.description: use stoichiometry to solve problems related to chemical reactions involving gases (e.g., problems involving moles, number of atoms, number of molecules, mass, and volume)

F5E231D5EFE84072901B716231ABC705.description: solve quantitative problems by performing calculations based on Boyle's law, Charles's law, Gay-Lussac's law, the combined gas law, Dalton's law of partial pressures, and the ideal gas law

DBACCEAFB4F645A4AF997DDDBF571D16.description: determine, through inquiry, the quantitative and graphical relationships between the pressure, volume, and temperature of a gas

EE719B178637490798CC476897608C12.description: use appropriate terminology related to gases and atmospheric chemistry, including, but not limited to: standard temperature, standard pressure, molar volume, and ideal gas

A2DC86EFA4BF4A5BBCF276FF8CC793B1.description: Developing Skills of Investigation and Communication: investigate gas laws that explain the behaviour of gases, and solve related problems;

922F86B7CB544185A372C81B4A243AD8.description: assess air quality conditions for a given Canadian location, using Environment Canada's Air Quality Health Index, and report on some Canadian initiatives to improve air quality and reduce greenhouse gases (e.g., Ontario's Drive Clean program to control vehicle emissions)

AEFCB36AF99948739D66C892977F0D4F.description: analyse the effects on air quality of some technologies and human activities (e.g., smelting; driving gas-powered vehicles), including their own activities, and propose actions to reduce their personal carbon footprint

211118C9C501442D91F77C514BB4A117.description: Relating Science to Technology, Society, and the Environment: analyse the cumulative effects of human activities and technologies on air quality, and describe some Canadian initiatives to reduce air pollution, including ways to reduce their own carbon footprint;

ABC16CF91515421995957A1330E56C38.description: explain the difference between strong and weak acids, and between strong and weak bases, in terms of degree of ionization

44657CAB887F43B88546CB77D7F1CCC5.description: explain the Arrhenius theory of acids and bases

77B3BEF3E9724F7DB34740A9ECEBE13F.description: identify, using a solubility table, the formation of precipitates in aqueous solutions (e.g., the use of iron or aluminum compounds to precipitate and remove phosphorus from wastewater)

55288104C99A4F62834046305795F985.description: explain the effects of changes in temperature and pressure on the solubility of solids, liquids, and gases (e.g., explain how a change in temperature or atmospheric pressure affects the solubility of oxygen in lake water)

9AB87FEA2F684C9D92C6F6A8FD8D8CBA.description: explain the process of formation for solutions that are produced by dissolving ionic and molecular compounds (e.g., salt, oxygen) in water, and for solutions that are produced by dissolving non-polar solutes in non-polar solvents (e.g., grease in vegetable oil)

7A7B7CBF60894A57B1997F3D8F1CEA2A.description: describe the properties of water (e.g., polarity, hydrogen bonding), and explain why these properties make water such a good solvent

5B7994D6F23C4A4CA1F7AFB80F9B4998.description: Understanding Basic Concepts: demonstrate an understanding of qualitative and quantitative properties of solutions

AB68EFAA9864494AA250CECF11453B34.description: conduct an investigation to determine the concentrations of pollutants in their local treated drinking water, and compare the results to commonly used guidelines and standards (e.g., provincial and federal standards)

AC3C3ED38ABC4C6E84B95AF8F0E53AF8.description: determine the concentration of an acid or a base in a solution (e.g., the concentration of acetic acid in vinegar), using the acid-base titration technique

AF4C63F722ED40928CFD47BB39FFBBF3.description: use stoichiometry to solve problems involving solutions and solubility

AF9A3D66E6E3486E8D4FAF7C30A55821.description: write balanced net ionic equations to represent precipitation and neutralization reactions

63E694FE172B4E1BAE0569791293EF82.description: conduct an investigation to analyse qualitative and quantitative properties of solutions (e.g., perform a qualitative analysis of ions in a solution)

C26287E7FDD541A5B7996A6D68A04A67.description: prepare solutions of a given concentration by dissolving a solid solute in a solvent or by diluting a concentrated solution

C229C8E263F34A438237A7DD4FD5A2F1.description: solve problems related to the concentration of solutions by performing calculations involving moles, and express the results in various units (e.g., moles per litre, grams per 100 mL, parts per million or parts per billion, mass, volume per cent)

1BCA1575C0644419885C4C0DFBF0B563.description: use appropriate terminology related to aqueous solutions and solubility, including, but not limited to: concentration, solubility, precipitate, ionization, dissociation, pH, dilute, solute, and solvent

E6113709915345B980B5C952954D7E1D.description: Developing Skills of Investigation and Communication: investigate qualitative and quantitative properties of solutions, and solve related problems;

B5E13F64857D4EBB82CDC568C85E7BED.description: analyse economic, social, and environmental issues related to the distribution, purification, or use of drinking water (e.g., the impact on the environment of the use of bottled water)

AEBE777382AC4CE6ACEF83C46EE10D54.description: analyse the origins and cumulative effects of pollutants that enter our water systems (e.g., landfill leachates, agricultural run-off, industrial effluents, chemical spills), and explain how these pollutants affect water quality

36DF42BA062445A090DEA668481A0C41.description: Relating Science to Technology, Society, and the Environment: analyse the origins and effects of water pollution, and a variety of economic, social, and environmental issues related to drinking water;

EC6F456004BC4535B63CE82EB0957C9F.description: explain the quantitative relationships expressed in a balanced chemical equation, using appropriate units of measure (e.g., moles, grams, atoms, ions, molecules)

6D5BD6FB54CA428FA183A3ADA0C55571.description: explain the relationship between the empirical formula and the molecular formula of a chemical compound

6326E22F58E949349F7E988244C468EE.description: describe the relationships between Avogadro's number, the mole concept, and the molar mass of any given substance

AFC297973E414334BA7B848449DDDC65.description: explain the law of definite proportions

901F53548E804CC7B108C72D061E75DE.description: Understanding Basic Concepts: demonstrate an understanding of the mole concept and its significance to the quantitative analysis of chemical reactions

6B66A001DBE342CA9561748E0EE352FA.description: conduct an inquiry to determine the actual yield, theoretical yield, and percentage yield of the products of a chemical reaction (e.g., a chemical reaction between steel wool and copper(II) sulfate solution), assess the effectiveness of the procedure, and suggest sources of experimental error

34CA114349D442AE8F084646F36273E4.description: solve problems related to quantities in chemical reactions by performing calculations involving percentage yield and limiting reagents

1D882AEE433A4E97BDDF4F5205371FAA.description: calculate the corresponding mass, or quantity in moles or molecules, for any given reactant or product in a balanced chemical equation as well as for any other reactant or product in the chemical reaction

83CF0A0400F144B599C40914C5E7E717.description: determine the empirical formulae and molecular formulae of various chemical compounds, given molar masses and percentage composition or mass data

992EC83206EB4A29A232EAD6BEC85E20.description: solve problems related to quantities in chemical reactions by performing calculations involving quantities in moles, number of particles, and atomic mass

E986F62ADE3B495898D19A49C6E815A8.description: conduct an inquiry to calculate the percentage composition of a compound (e.g., a hydrate)

2FEC35A1640C4F5590533ABEDA5BB823.description: use appropriate terminology related to quantities in chemical reactions, including, but not limited to: stoichiometry, percentage yield, limiting reagent, mole, and atomic mass

2E22BB39086B463CBA79644B6CE61477.description: Developing Skills of Investigation and Communication: investigate quantitative relationships in chemical reactions, and solve related problems;

6DFFA7F43C1F4A018A2260A39D258860.description: assess, on the basis of research, the importance of quantitative accuracy in industrial chemical processes and the potential impact on the environment if quantitative accuracy is not observed

27F5CD80417F4B1AA8A97ADE7F9F5A62.description: analyse processes in the home, the workplace, and the environmental sector that involve the use of chemical quantities and calculations (e.g., mixing household cleaning solutions, calculating chemotherapy doses, monitoring pollen counts)

299310ACC1EA46C6BF1799150B8E2358.description: Relating Science to Technology, Society, and the Environment: analyse processes in the home, the workplace, and the environmental sector that use chemical quantities and calculations, and assess the importance of quantitative accuracy in industrial chemical processes;

17F7E9CE8D334D75BB2D768BDBCE099E.description: explain the chemical reactions that result in the formation of acids and bases from metal oxides and non-metal oxides (e.g., calcium oxide reacts with water to produce a basic solution; carbon dioxide reacts with water to produce an acidic solution

E60052DC6B9F477CBD0D1B670847A79D.description: explain the difference between a complete combustion reaction and an incomplete combustion reaction (e.g., complete and incomplete combustion of hydrocarbon fuels)

68048560C7A243C2A889FFF4467F9EBD.description: identify various types of chemical reactions, including synthesis, decomposition, single displacement, double displacement, and combustion

E64D1D77EB0B48C0A2C31BBD6F0D0F55.description: Understanding Basic Concepts: demonstrate an understanding of the different types of chemical reactions.

908726EC25D14B3EA2AC8E5F2D70731E.description: plan and conduct an inquiry to demonstrate a single displacement reaction, using elements from the metal activity series

B506CA2A10FB4F4B8163E261E0A08234.description: investigate neutralization reactions (e.g., neutralize a dilute solution of sodium hydroxide with a dilute solution of hydrochloric acid, and isolate the sodium chloride produced)

C47D4F03088047819CF0398288508503.description: plan and conduct an inquiry to compare the properties of non-metal oxide solutions and metal oxide solutions (e.g., carbon dioxide reacts with water to make water acidic; magnesium oxide reacts with water to make water basic)

6F1A632CE80440449DA7DC69F224557C.description: design an inquiry to demonstrate the difference between a complete and an incomplete combustion reaction

B19037B729694884976BE6896FF456AF.description: predict the products of double displacement reactions (e.g., the formation of precipitates or gases; neutralization)

9AB461CCB35D43DB8AEACDDFF3675C8C.description: predict the products of single displacement reactions, using the metal activity series and the halogen series

A8F9EF1B1664437C9964101E912AA700.description: predict the products of different types of synthesis and decomposition reactions (e.g., synthesis reactions in which simple compounds are formed; synthesis reactions of metallic or non-metallic oxides with water; decomposition reactions, in which a chemical compound is separated into several compounds)

BCED2DA1F1404BEA982E65714DF67D36.description: investigate synthesis, decomposition, single displacement, and double displacement reactions, by testing the products of each reaction (e.g., test for products such as gases, the presence of an acid, or the presence of a base)

E08B9BD49BE54691B2BB91E9A94F918A.description: write balanced chemical equations to represent synthesis, decomposition, single displacement, double displacement, and combustion reactions, using the IUPAC nomenclature system

1EEA5AAD6981452C93719D9F126B4D4E.description: use appropriate terminology related to chemical reactions, including, but not limited to: neutralization, precipitate, acidic, and basic

707ACDCA2169416E99D3432D6759B2AF.description: Developing Skills of Investigation and Communication: investigate different types of chemical reactions;

948E63A37BF84BF788B9392600477EF5.description: assess the effectiveness of some applications of chemical reactions that are used to address social and environmental needs and problems

D54C5254388F40C3B12AE8FA04619695.description: analyse, on the basis of research, chemical reactions used in various industrial processes (e.g., pulp and paper production, mining, chemical manufacturing) that can have an impact on the health and safety of local populations

5BC804E974BC441985CF2A2B89040480.description: Relating Science to Technology, Society, and the Environment: analyse chemical reactions used in a variety of applications, and assess their impact on society and the environment;

9236A55634244BF5A617418318F6F022.description: compare and contrast the physical properties of ionic and molecular compounds (e.g., NaCl and CH4 ; NaOH and H2 O)

1D60BCC869644874888E59077DB4D7D8.description: explain the differences between the formation of ionic bonds and the formation of covalent bonds

E7A9DCB092D44E9AA65B8E77D779217E.description: state the periodic law, and explain how patterns in the electron arrangement and forces in atoms result in periodic trends (e.g., in atomic radius, ionization energy, electron affinity, electronegativity) in the periodic table

04971AD370DC478988921E831EF85C34.description: explain the relationship between isotopic abundance of an element's isotopes and the relative atomic mass of the element

8CAC4765574747CCA1FE91519BED597B.description: explain the relationship between the atomic number and the mass number of an element, and the difference between isotopes and radioisotopes of an element

E0231F00260C43A3A759723143F0F02E.description: Understanding Basic Concepts: demonstrate an understanding of periodic trends in the periodic table and how elements combine to form chemical bonds.

ED483DF8755745BABB84C0997546611C.description: write chemical formulae of binary and polyatomic compounds, including those with multiple valences, and name the compounds using the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) nomenclature system

EA5880CBFA6E48058D7672B48E234806.description: build molecular models, and write structural formulae, for molecular compounds containing single and multiple bonds (e.g., CO2 , H2 O, C2 H4 ), and for ionic crystalline structures (e.g., NaCl)

5D480E5892F84D9EA159022259D460D6.description: predict the nature of a bond (e.g., non-polar covalent, polar covalent, ionic), using electronegativity values of atoms

ACE0CF6F91174A62BF1F1C0B4D098D33.description: draw Lewis structures to represent the bonds in ionic and molecular compounds

09561DF772294CEA96CB6BFA26BD0987.description: use an inquiry process to investigate the chemical reactions of elements (e.g., metals, non-metals) with other substances (e.g., oxygen, acids, water), and produce an activity series using the resulting data

F2ABE52C69AD4DDD8CC39B1A7C5B4214.description: analyse data related to the properties of elements within a period (e.g., ionization energy, atomic radius) to identify general trends in the periodic table

F3C66765ED88417593AB3640F2E348A2.description: use appropriate terminology related to chemical trends and chemical bonding, including, but not limited to: atomic radius, effective nuclear charge, electronegativity, ionization energy, and electron affinity

62F6F9720AD640A18B142F72A5404E81.description: Developing Skills of Investigation and Communication: investigate physical and chemical properties of elements and compounds, and use various methods to visually represent them;

A4523CC1918141F7AB677A8F42994CF8.description: evaluate the risks and benefits to human health of some commonly used chemical substances (e.g., chemical additives in foods; pharmaceuticals; cosmetics and perfumes; household cleaning products)

82808B0D61ED46C89112F5822F94D7A5.description: analyse, on the basis of research, the properties of a commonly used but potentially harmful chemical substance (e.g., fertilizer, pesticide, a household cleaning product, materials used in electronics and batteries) and how that substance affects the environment, and propose ways to lessen the harmfulness of the substance (e.g., by reducing the amount used, by modifying one of its chemical components) or identify alternative substances that could be used for the same purpose

CC66DFF550B04D91A17A6C2C3E98E373.description: Relating Science to Technology, Society, and the Environment: analyse the properties of commonly used chemical substances and their effects on human health and the environment, and propose ways to lessen their impact;

7ADE6F48F81E4DB58842E7F94CBA8503.description: Matter, Chemical Trends, and Chemical Bonding

DA9F914AFC0E4E8B9C7C753D465E3AB8.description: describe the contributions of scientists, including Canadians (e.g., Carol Ann Budd, Edgar Steacie, Raymond Lemieux, Louis Taillefer, F. Kenneth Hare), to the fields under study

8BAA5E98155949619B84C27DFFB6BD79.description: identify and describe a variety of careers related to the fields of science under study (e.g., pharmacist, forensic scientist, chemical engineer, food scientist, environmental chemist, occupational health and safety officer, water quality analyst, atmospheric scientist) and the education and training necessary for these careers

4D21277506634A80850CCF106B77070D.description: Career Exploration: . identify and describe careers related to the fields of science under study, and describe the contributions of scientists, including Canadians, to those fields

D961F13655DC4ECA9A1C3A78B0976A5C.description: express the results of any calculations involving data accurately and precisely, to the appropriate number of decimal places or significant figures

986DE176E0684BF391D309781F63D91D.description: use appropriate numeric, symbolic, and graphic modes of representation, and appropriate units of measurement (e.g., SI and imperial units)

50EF132479594E55A57F671FA54DC2FE.description: communicate ideas, plans, procedures, results, and conclusions orally, in writing, and/or in electronic presentations, using appropriate language and a variety of formats (e.g., data tables, laboratory reports, presentations, debates, simulations, models)

D4216CFC66C54F959C09068F310069F9.description: draw conclusions based on inquiry results and research findings, and justify their conclusions with reference to scientific knowledge

BE73F83D9145442482FE1F7EFFF5312A.description: analyse the information gathered from research sources for logic, accuracy, reliability, adequacy, and bias

2487BB54542444E49F3898A5B599B13C.description: synthesize, analyse, interpret, and evaluate qualitative and quantitative data; solve problems involving quantitative data; determine whether the evidence supports or refutes the initial prediction or hypothesis and whether it is consistent with scientific theory; identify sources of bias and error; and suggest improvements to the inquiry to reduce the likelihood of error

7FFDB838762243DABA86155FCB502B8D.description: select, organize, and record relevant information on research topics from a variety of appropriate sources, including electronic, print, and/or human sources, using suitable formats and an accepted form of academic documentation

7C63BA75DE144B56B194839152800F52.description: compile accurate data from laboratory and other sources, and organize and record the data, using appropriate formats, including tables, flow charts, graphs, and/or diagrams

D4CDD989BE124030AE3086FF7B99737F.description: conduct inquiries, controlling relevant variables, adapting or extending procedures as required, and using appropriate materials and equipment safely, accurately, and effectively, to collect observations and data

643A522DA68943AD9E154C8B62C6C091.description: apply knowledge and understanding of safe laboratory practices and procedures when planning investigations by correctly interpreting Workplace Hazardous Materials Information System (WHMIS) symbols; by using appropriate techniques for handling and storing laboratory equipment and materials and disposing of laboratory materials; and by using appropriate personal protection (e.g., wearing safety goggles)

BC01FDCF63964AA89FCB53488107ADAD.description: identify and locate a variety of print and electronic sources that enable them to address research topics fully and appropriately

1144CF2EF1F045869AF9B33EFD192E5D.description: select appropriate instruments (e.g., a balance, glassware, titration instruments) and materials (e.g., molecular model kits, solutions), and identify appropriate methods, techniques, and procedures, for each inquiry

BCB6764A4DE64CD0B7261C33E498F0B3.description: formulate relevant scientific questions about observed relationships, ideas, problems, or issues, make informed predictions, and/or formulate educated hypotheses to focus inquiries or research

479400D924FE480396FC2D587E2C03D0.description: Scientific Investigation Skills: demonstrate scientific investigation skills (related to both inquiry and research) in the four areas of skills (initiating and planning, performing and recording, analysing and interpreting, and communicating);

185FB787844D43CCB84591A09451F0DC.description: Scientific Investigation Skills and Career Exploration
